Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Oblique and Brachy Axis Approaches for Continuous Adductor Canal Block in Total Knee Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: This single-center, randomized, parallel-group, double-blind trial involved 90 patients undergoing unilateral TKA.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to receive ultrasound-guided CACB using either the OA or BA.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the oblique approach (OA) versus the brachy axis approach (BA) for CACB, focusing on analgesic outcomes and adverse reactions.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the exercise maximum visual analog scale (VAS) score at 72 hours post-surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomization was computer-generated, with allocation concealed in opaque envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was maintained for patients, clinicians, and outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Ninety participants were randomized: 45 to the OA group and 45 to the BA group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The OA group demonstrated significantly lower exercise VAS scores at 72 hours (p < 0.05) and a reduced incidence of adverse reactions compared to the BA group.

Harms.evidence: Adverse reactions were more frequent in the BA group, including swelling and pain at the catheter site.

Trial_Registration.evidence: Trial Registration: Chinese Clinical Trial Registry: ChiCTR2200059889.
